channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Scientists Are Measuring Ocean Currents in Hopes of Charting AMOC’s Future
item.description: Scientists fear warming is driving a collapse in the ocean currents that shape climate far and wide. The ice-choked waters off Greenland might hold the key.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Esther Horvath
item.media:description: Scoresby Sound, a fjord in eastern Greenland, as seen from the research ship.

item.title: Could President Trump Bring Japan’s Tiny Cars to America? Not So Fast.
item.description: Mr. Trump is pushing to approve their production in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: A Japanese kei-car sits in a garage in Sapporo, Japan.

item.title: An Alaskan Village Confronts Its Changing Climate: Rebuild or Relocate?
item.description: After a devastating storm, the people who fled a remote coastal village face an existential question.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance and Katie Basile
item.media:description: Maggie Paul in her hotel room in Anchorage after her home was destroyed by Typhoon Halong. However long it takes to rebuild the village, Ms. Paul said, “I will wait.”

item.title: A Look at What Lives Where Deep Sea Mining Would Happen
item.description: An ocean-mining company has funded some of the most comprehensive scientific studies of the deep seabed to date, and peer-reviewed results have begun to emerge.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Federal Judge Finds Trump’s Halt on Wind Energy Is Illegal
item.description: The president ordered a stop to permits for all wind farms on federal lands and waters. A judge called that “capricious.”
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vineyard Wind Farm, about 15 miles south of the coast of Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts.

item.title: MAHA Activists Urge Trump to Fire Lee Zeldin at the E.P.A.
item.description: As head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lee Zeldin has weakened protections against toxic chemicals, say members of the MAHA movement.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A petition to fire Lee Zeldin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, had more than 2,800 signatures by midday Friday.

item.title: Lots of Oil, Little Production: What to Know About Venezuelan Energy
item.description: The South American country increasingly at odds with the Trump administration has the world’s largest oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Lazaro Gamio
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Shigeru Ban: How Architects Can Respond to Natural Disasters
item.description: Architects are uniquely positioned to help people displaced by natural disasters.
item.dc:creator: Shigeru Ban
item.media:description: Volunteers build a Paper Log House in Maui, Hawaii, after a wildfire there in 2023. The house is made of plywood, paper tubes and other local materials, and was designed to be built in a short period of time to help speed up disaster relief efforts.

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: Higher Prices, Less Coverage: Your Stories of the Home Insurance Crunch
item.description: Readers told us how insurers are raising premiums and, in some cases, cutting back coverage, as climate change shakes up the real estate market.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:description: Home insurance prices have risen drastically in areas most exposed to climate-related risk, like California and Florida. And research shows the effects of the higher rates are also spilling over into the broader real estate market.

item.title: Climate Shift Upends Atlantic Seaweed: One Massive Patch Grows as Another Vanishes
item.description: Blooms of yellowish-brown seaweed along the Equator are breaking records and defiling beaches, while a centuries-old patch farther north is disappearing.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: Mexican National Guard members during a sargassum seaweed cleanup event in Cancun, Mexico, in June.

item.title: Trump Returns to Gasoline as Fuel of Choice for Cars, Gutting Biden’s Climate Policy
item.description: The president said he would weaken Biden-era mileage standards, which were designed to increase electric-vehicle sales, calling them a “scam.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Jack Ewing
item.media:description: President Trump, surrounded by executives from the auto industry, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: Nature Retracts Study Predicting Catastrophic Climate Toll
item.description: While growing evidence shows that carbon emissions are harming the economy, the journal Nature found that an outlier paper had deep flaws.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.category: Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Canada Turns to the World’s Polar Bear Capital to Defend its Arctic
item.description: The tiny town of Churchill has two of Canada’s largest pieces of Arctic infrastructure, but years of neglect have left them in poor shape amid growing superpower rivalry in the region.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tundra outside Churchill, Manitoba, the so-called polar bear capital of the world.

item.title: Environmentally Friendly Coffee
item.description: Here’s what to know about your daily brew and the environment.
item.dc:creator: Kate Selig
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Shutterstock

item.title: Trump Expected to Significantly Weaken Fuel Economy Rules
item.description: Executives from top automakers were invited to attend the announcement at the White House on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:description: The Biden-era auto emissions rules have significantly reduced the planet-warming greenhouse gases from transportation, which is the single largest source of carbon pollution in the United States.

item.title: Reckoning With a New Era of Deadly Floods
item.description: The floods and landslides that have killed more than 1,350 people in recent weeks are a grim reminder of the risks of a warming planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Debris left by flash flooding in Batang Toru, North Sumatra, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Sharks and Rays Gain Sweeping Protections from Wildlife Trade
item.description: A global treaty has extended trade protections to more than 70 shark and ray species whose numbers are in sharp decline.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: The Philippines Spent Big on Flood Control, but the Water Keeps Rising
item.description: Many Filipinos say floods are worse than ever — and now, the government has admitted that vast sums were embezzled from a program meant to fight the problem.
item.dc:creator: Aie Balagtas See and Jes Aznar
item.media:description: Wading through flooded streets on Saturday in Calumpit, a city in the northern Philippines.

item.title: It’s No Dodo, But This Newly Discovered Bird Could Share the Same Fate
item.description: The slaty-masked tinamou, recently discovered in Brazil, is utterly unafraid of people. That could be its undoing, ornithologists worry.
item.dc:creator: Joe Trezza

item.title: FEMA Won’t Reinstate Suspended Workers Who Signed Letter Criticizing Trump
item.description: Employees suspended in the summer after signing a letter critical of the president were told they could return to work. But the reinstatement was short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A FEMA search and rescue worker in Swannanoa, N.C., after Hurricane Helene last year.

item.title: Inside the Bird-Flu Vaccine Trial for Monk Seals
item.description: After the virus returned to Hawaii this fall, testing the shots in the endangered seal species became urgent.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Loren Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: Zillow Removes Climate Risk Scores From Home Listings
item.description: The scores aimed to predict a property’s risk from fires, floods and storms, but some in the real estate industry as well as homeowners have called them inaccurate.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A flooded neighborhood in Punta Gorda, Fla., after Hurricane Milton last year.

item.title: Many Fighting Climate Change Worry They Are Losing the Information War
item.description: Shifting politics, intensive lobbying and surging disinformation online have undermined international efforts to respond to the threat.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Oil-rich countries, including the U.S., are downplaying scientific consensus that the burning of fossil fuels is dangerously heating the planet.

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Beekeepers, Farmers and the Fight to Save a Century-Old Research Hub
item.description: Industry groups and scientists have urged the Trump administration to reconsider its plan to close a renowned Agriculture Department center in Maryland and disperse its work around the country.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu

item.title: The New York Neighborhoods That Best Protect Against Extreme Heat
item.description: The city’s new climate budgeting program is investing billions in keeping the city cool as the climate gets hotter.
item.dc:creator: Akiva Blander
item.media:description: Tottenville, on the southern tip of Staten Island, is among New York’s coolest neighborhoods.

item.title: E.P.A. Delays Requirements to Cut Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
item.description: Oil and gas firms were supposed to start reducing methane, a powerful driver of climate change. The agency is giving them more time and may cancel the requirement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas flare at an oil facility in Midland, Texas.

item.title: New York City’s Next Super Storm
item.description: What’s a worst-case scenario for hurricane flooding in New York City? Our reporter Hilary Howard, who covers the environment in the region, explores how bad it could get as climate change powers increasingly extreme rainfall and devastating storm surges.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard, Gabriel Blanco, Stephanie Swart and K.K. Rebecca Lai

item.title: Trump Vowed Fewer Regulations and Lots More Oil. He’s Delivered on One.
item.description: The president’s energy strategy is projected to generate more pollution, but so far production has not risen significantly and price drops have been modest, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Since President Trump took office, oil production is up, but largely because of improved efficiency, and it has not translated into more jobs for either the industry or the overall economy.

item.title: The Broken Circle
item.description: Farmers in Northwest China confront their drying landscape by planting trees as coal burns relentlessly nearby. This film tells a human story behind an element from the periodic table: carbon.
item.dc:creator: Zhao Liang

item.title: The Tourism Slump Squeezes Navajo Nation Parks Like Monument Valley
item.description: Things were looking up last year at pandemic-battered Navajo Nation parks. Then their lifeblood, foreign visitors, slowed to a trickle.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:description: Monument Valley draws tourists to the Navajo Nation, the largest Native American reservation in the U.S.

item.title: Tentative Signs of Hope as the Amazon Burns
item.description: This year’s U.N. climate negotiations were seen by activists as a letdown. But a Times reporter found some encouraging signs on the ground in the Brazilian Amazon.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters working to contain a wildfire on degraded pastureland on the fringes of Paragominas, Brazil. Fire, not logging, is now the greatest threat to the world’s largest tropical forest.
